As a life long fan of Formula one my opinion will always be clouded by sentiment. I've owned every game since 2010 so feel I understand the game well enough.

The handling this year is better (easier). I'm making corners I always used to struggle with. Traction this year is more difficult than previous years though.

Speech recognition is less bugged this year. (It actually works straight of the bat)

The graphics have improved since last year.

The addition of "MyTeam" is excellent and I really enjoy all the additional elements instead of just racing. I really hope they expand on this in the next version. 

The car models are as always on point.

What I don't like are the micro-transactions. This has caused a lot of cosmetics to now be hidden behind a pay wall. At least give us a more basic choice if you are going to have pay-cosmetics.

For me (mostly because of the introduction of "MyTeam") this is the best version in many years. It would have been the best if not for the micro-transactions.

Worth buying and I'm sure this will end up being my most played F1 game.

F1 2020

Yet another yearly F1 title by Codemasters. As the game is now on a 40% sale, I feel inclined to finally voice my opinion on the game and if you should buy the game or not during the sale.

F1 2019 was largely an improvement over F1 2018, featuring a substantial graphical upgrade, codemasters proudly showing off the night race at Bahrain in the first promo videos. Furthermore, the biggest addition in F1 2019 was the implementation of the Formula 2 feeder series into the game. F1 2019 also added driver transfers into the carrer mode keeping while keeping the R&D from F1 2018 (more on this later). 

So, what does F1 2020 offer new and returning players? Micro-transactions, in-game items previously accessible from the get-go, now locked behind a limited 60day event, where you are required to fulfill certain challenges (or spend real money) to obtain the items. However, many more items are added to the game (though you have to buy them indirectly with real money or complete certain challanges) 

But, f1 2020's primary addition to the series is a brand new career mode where you create your own team called "MyTeam". However the system is extremely limited in terms of what you are allowed to do in game. Tried to name your racing team you play in SINGLE PLAYER after an historical team or manufacturer and found out you couldn't do it? Tried to do work arounds using numbers instead of letters etc? Your account just got BANNED, sorry. God forbid having your player name be of "Historical Significance" DIE RACIST. Coming back to talk about actual game-play, the mode is extremely easy, months after release. Playing after 2 seasons for any decent player is pointless as your team easily snowballs into an unstoppable force leaving many players to call the mode an "Mercedes Simulator". 

Another point is the supposed "Performance Patch" we are still waiting on everyone thought we were going to have months/weeks ago. Due to Ferrari's massive drop in performance from 2019 to 2020 nobody could have expected, (unless you actually listened to what Ferrari said during pre-season testing including Fia's tec directive, adding 1+1 was too hard for most of us) The game ends up being a horrible representation of real F1, while Vettel and Ferrari are struggling like never before irl, they are winning race after race in the video game. 

In Conclusion the game is arguable the best game codemasters have ever developed with more features than ever before. And while I do recommend you buy the game on a discount, the game ends up getting a "Not Recommended" due to the massive video-game SIN of adding micro-transaction to a already 40$+ racing game. Not aligning itself up to real F1 in any shape or form. And lastly, Ignoring it's communities feedback regarding the R&D speed that has been an issue since 2017.

One of the best simulation racing games ever made, right up there with GT and Forza series.  This is my first F1 game and I am just scratching the surface right now learning about all the intricacies of F1 (not super knowledgeable fan of F1). I am barely competitive at AI 20% even though I have played racing games forever, including Codemasters own GRID series.  But I really like how we can fine tune the difficulty percentage-wise so everyone can find a level of competition they enjoy, rather than your normal Easy/Medium/Hard settings in other games.  Xbox controller works well enough for this game but might need a racing wheel to really master the turns and throttle control.

Dope game

Incredibly lazy developers who have proved themselves unable to add 2020 F2 cars which was a matter of changing a few wheels and liveries, unable to add tracks from this season, and even remove a few venues, and unable to update the performance of just two damn cars. I initially reviewed this game as a positive because of the handling, but once again lazy development ruins the show.

It is a great game, and truly something going towards the right direction. Let me list some pros and cons the game has:
PROS
-My Team career mode (unlike anything we've ever seen before)
-All DLC from previous games has been added to this game (except for the Senna and Prost characters, as far as I've seen)
-Simplified ERS (the 2018 and 2019 versions, you had to change every 0.33 seconds or so)
-Better graphics
-Addition of Split-screen
-Addition of Hanoi Street circuit and Zandvoort circuit
-Schumacher DLC
-all integrations of the teams versions of the #WeRaceAsOne liveries were implemented
-F2 2019 (the only complaint that I have with this, is that we can hire Antoine Hubert for our My Team career modes, even though he died at Spa (RIP Hubert) and I do understand his conclusion in the F2 part, but why are you able to hire him in the 2020 F1 season?)
-Cars feel waay faster
-The possibility of saving race highlights (it was in 2019 as well, but it's good to see it do its thing here)
-Making the game more Casual-friendly by changing some settings within the game (allowing people who aren't good at the game jump in, regardless of their skills)
-Increased realism on the physics

CONS
-Podium pass (just why?)
-Microtransactions (was this deleoped by EA or something?)
-Zandvoort feels like it's from 1970 instead of what it should've been in 2020
-Zandvoort marshalling sectors feel waaay off, as I once had a yellow in the final corner, which also resulted in a yellow on the pit-straight
-The lack of Steam Remote-Play support
-The inability to hire Nico Hulkenberg as a teammate in My Team (I can't be the only one who wants to give him another shot)
-The lack of a 'alternate layout' to Zandvoort, as I feel you can make a shorter variant of Zandvoort using the diffrent layouts
-The AI starts feel waaaay too sluggish on a pad/wheel. on keyboard, they are just fine but that is because you need TCS on full when playing on a keyboard. when on medium or none, the ai get some good reactions, but then it feels like they bog down. I actually made up 8 position at monza going into T1 with a wheel, and I started P20.

Overall, it's a great game. If I could request one thing to codemasters directly, it's to add the Steam Remote-Play support so I can play with my friends who don't own a gaming PC and/or the game itself. the game is really Casual friendly, and is easy to jump into wether you are a pro or just starting out. definetely CodeMaster's best game to date. If I had to rate the game a a number/10, it would get a solid 8.4/10

(side note, I will keep updating this review when a pro/con gets removed/added from my personal list)
The game is just amazing! I love the My Team Career Mode. There are a few things that need to be fixed, changed and added, but as a whole the game is really damn solid! I love it!

Wheel support for G29 is amazing. Overall an improvement from F1 2019 (Except for ranked mp, it's still the same). Creating your own team was a highly requested feature and I'm glad they added it. 

The major turnoff is ranked multiplayer, it's still the cesspool that we have known since the earlier titles. If you actually want to enjoy multiplayer, join a league or play unranked with your friends. Safety rating still sucks and needs a major overhaul; you could qualify in the top 3, have a nice clean start and then someone rams you... and then, guess what, you get a warning for collision and that will decrease your safety rating. Ranked honestly isn't worth it. Also, the track limits in time trial and one-shot qualifying is ass.

F1 2020, in my opinion, is in the top 2 or 3 of all the F1 games. While this is not a sim, I would call it a simcade. This is the closest that the F1 series of games has got to being a sim but you can still change the traction control, anti lock brakes etc. to make it easier. While I have seen that some have experienced some bugs in this game, I have not. I would absolutely recommend F1 2020 to any gamer that is also an F1 fan.    
   F1 2020 seems well optimized. I can run it almost maxed out at 1920x1080 in DX12 at a consistent 60 FPS.

Windows 10
i5-4460

AI is a nightmare. Same old bugs. None of the features of games that have been on the market for a decade. Crazy.

"You've played 11 more hours of this game, would you like to revise your review?"

OK. I am fucking sick of getting 3 second penalties for running wide and losing time. Unfuckingbelievable.

Further: Now regularly getting errors trying to join MP lobbies. Cars crashing in a race left a phantom wheel in the middle of the track but no safety car. Safety car bug still exists, glitching it or cars on track when they pit. Crash to desktop loading setups in MP lobbies on more than one occasion, fortunately in practice sessions. Daniel Ricciardo suddenly went out in a Merc in one MP session with no AI...

Patch 1.09 - Fixes none of the issues we've been having in a league. Start lights go out early for the host and spectators, random disconnects and races getting stuck on the start lights. Penalties are still more often applied to the person rear-ended than the offender. 
Also, most time trial times have been randomly replaced with ones of a different time, and claims to be using setups when not and vice versa. Total farce. Codemasters got real lucky real racing is happening and people aren't seeing real F1 drivers face these issues week in week out.

Let me just start off by saying I LOVE racing games, so what better game to play then Formula 1. 

I have never played any Formula 1 games before this one, and mainly originally only purchased it because it was on a 50% sale and I only ended up spending around $40 for the Special Edition (really good deal).

However, this game has everything one would hope to find in a Formula 1 game, pre race analytics, weather updates, etc.l

My most favourite feature is probably the career mode where you can own a Formula 1 team, and compete as a driver and own the team. Really cool feature to allow players to do that, and has good supporting dialog to follow the story. I also really enjoy the feature of allowing you to talk to the press. Although I wish there was more to it, it is nice to see more games adopting the 2K story line of allowing you to interact with a "press" that dictates things like Aclaim, department morale etc. 

Really enjoy playing this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys racing games for what they are ~ racing cars, or, in this case, Formula 1 cars.

If you're not a car guy like me, it's better to start with the Driver Career to get accustomed to the ways of F1 before moving on with the My Team Career.

Also what's great is you can adjust the difficulty quite well that suits your enjoyment. Let's be honest, most of us just want to enjoy and win, so it's not bad swinging that difficulty down, no shame in that.

For its price it's well worth it the $25 I paid for.

Such a complete game, there a lot of changes compared to last year's version. 

Here are some pros:

The new gameplay mode: My Team, is a total success, its really fun to take decisiosn about where you should invest the money and what drivers select as your teammate. The customization of the team its also really cool. all of this makes you want to play it for multiple seasons.

The sound of the car and other track effects (crashes, wall contact, sound echos went passing close to walls) were improved a lot. it feels more envolving.

The new ERS deployment its a fetarure that I enjoy a lot, and its more close to the real thing. no more having to cahnge deployment type before and after every turn, now you just have an "overtake button" that you can use to spend at will you stored energy.

I thins this is the best F1 game so far, totally recommended.

Being my first F1 game I have played since F1 2003 on the PS2, this game is just awesome, especially with a wheel. My online experience has however been mostly negative, due to the drivers i come across. My teams is great, with the practice programs to help learn all of the tracks (which I have needed to do).

The visual effects, especially in the wet on max settings are outstanding, as well as with the sound effects. Commentary in my teams specifically could do with a bigger variety of options and questions, however as a base line this year's game has been great. I will definitely be buying next years. It would be good to see more development options in the R&D screen, or pay staff wages who will improve your car faster etc, or buy a red bull pit crew.

If you are considering getting this game, I highly recommend it, even for new players.

TL;DR: Good upgrades on paper vs previous edition but bad execution for the most part.

For context, this is my second F1 game after 2019. I play singleplayer as well as take part in an amateur community league. I use an Xbox controller.

I really liked the addition of My Team mode in this year's version. It is a fun concept, but I have two major complaints so far:
1. The secondary driver you start with is often not a good match for you. Even with difficulty where my lap times are only a few tenths from the rest of the field, my secondary driver (Lord Mahaveer) is in the back of the field while I get pole.
2. The car upgrades concept was complex enough for me in 2019, with the additions of further upgrades, I am totally lost!

As far as main gameplay goes, it feels like car setups play too important a role for making the car go around a track well. The default setups have a lot of understeer issues, such as in the turn past the back DRS straight in Spain or a couple turns before the back DRS straight in Monaco. This can very well frustrate a new player using balanced setup. I haven't used the singleplayer assists yet but on paper they sound nice. Having a simplified ERS and DRS (including the assists) is a good touch IMO.

I was excited about the F1 league mode, but the bugs are filled with it and makes it a bad choice for adoption. Even many multiplayer issues have spilled over from previous game and many more have come. This has negatively impacted online play for many. It is still F1 and if you don't sweat, you can still enjoy the racing.

In the end, if you like F1 and want to enjoy racing, go ahead but don't take this game seriously. Also, the DLC is whack IMO as the vehicle models look awful in custom settings without a dedicated option.

For the Formula 1 experience (rules, flags, DRS zones, etc) this is the game for you.  The handling model is a significant improvement over 2019.  

2020 brings a bit more realism to the experience... Specifically with the introduction of the "overtake" button.  You can still manipulate your ERS in practice and quali sessions but, during the race your only option is the OT button.  

Avoid PVP unless you are setting up your own lobbies with friends...  Turn 1 is a cluster between people that don't care and, horrible connections forcing you off track.  Good luck finding a ranked lobby other than the 5 lap option.  

The My Team feature is interesting for those looking at the Driver/Owner aspect...  Ensure you dial in your AI before you launch your first season in My Team, otherwise you'll find yourself half a second ahead of 2nd place in a subpar car, with your teammate sitting comfortably in 22nd place.
If you press the Throttle harder, you go faster than your friends. 9/10 would win again

What I like:
-MyTeam is a wish come true. I had been longing for long for a F1 game where we can develop our own team. The complexity, the headache and the planning is amazing.

What I don't like:
-The game did crashes a few times. Each time it happen is under very different situation. It happen three time as of this review and it doesn't cause much trouble but still frustrated. This kind of event never happened when I played other games either on Steam or on other platform.
-The DLC which we need to pay for extra liveries and so on. This game is basically a giant and expensive DLC already. With gameplay, engine and physics of the game has little changes. The only changes are the team, liveries and calendar. So why not just included everything as we will still be buying this game every year.

What I like to see in the future:
-We can carry the liveries for the next and coming F1 game.
-Included all the circuit that ever hosted the F1 Grand Prix like Sepang.
-Customization of race calendar so we can put as many race as we want and able to add circuit which are not in the current calendar.
-Pits Team department in MyTeam so we can improve and upgrade. Pit stop is a huge part in the race.
-Maybe include the other racing class, F2 and F3 like the motoGP game.

Awesome game. Improves year on year. The new My Team section is excellent and although it could do with some tweaking here and there is real fun. I guess theres a risk is could have made the Career mode a bit redundant but I think that this section still has its merits. Codemasters unlike EA sports with Madden NFL and Sports Interactive with FM series really make the effort to listen to people within F1, the players of the game and the fans to push this series year on year to get better and better rather than just treading water. Also, absolute touch of genius to include Rags in the F2 drivers you can sign. Real comedy value. Handling is great and the game has a sliding scale from easy pedal to the metal style drivers with all assists on to a more immersive experience with all assists off, which when you eventually get it right rewards the hours of practice and patience. The MyTeam feature of this game is something I have been hoping for for many years, I even made such a suggestion back in 2018 when codemasters posted on facebook asking what features you'd like to see in the game. However, I do think they could have made it a TAD MORE customisable than it is, but still, it's a good starting point. Several issues from previous versions have been fixed, such as blue flagged cars moving out of the way, in 2019 it was terrible, but this has since been improved, however the AI still seems to struggle with the idea of racing etiquette such as on several occasions they will just swerve across the track into the side of you for no reason, they don't leave you enough room through corners when approaching from behind and have less than half a car alongside you etc... but these are just small things. The biggest issue with it currently though is the overall performance of the teams, such as Ferrari are still performing as a top 3 team, when in reality they are struggling down the mid-field or worse. It's a good game, looks great, plays nice, but there are still a few factors that I think could be improved, but again, these, mostly, don't affect actual game-play and are just more personal preferences like being able to customize the car livery in the style of Forza Motorsport, changing the appearance of car parts, such as the nose, wings, sidepods etc... these are just things I'D like to see in the game, but then, this is their first foray into the custom team thing, so these things may come in later games.

This game is very fun, but has a few very notable issues.Firstly, There is no 'end-game' motive in my-team. After a couple seasons, the in-game cash is meaningless, as are R&D resets. I personally lost interest after just two seasons, because of this.Secondly, The PitCoin. If you don't care very much about the liveries, PitCoin doesn't matter whatsoever. If you do care, you have to spend real money on it. If this game were free, I would understand and wouldn't care. But in order to get the VIP pass for the Podium Pass, you need 9,000 PitCoin. The issue with PitCoin is that you can't earn enough to get anything in-game. the non-VIP Podium Pass gives you only 2,500 PitCoin, and that is the only way to get PitCoin in-game. If either of these are dealt with I would most definitely recommend this game.

I'm huge fan racing games in general and more so of F1 games, played everything from PS2 era foward, games made by EA, Sony and now Codemasters...And Codemasters made some pretty good games since they got the license, always improving and adding new modes, features and etc... F1 2020 it's a another good entry on the franchise, My Team is a good addition to other career modes...But, and that it's a huge but, the Podium Pass is simply disgusting... I brought the more complete version of the game but since Podium Pass comes in seasons, I have to buy the Podium Pass each season (today the 2nd season started) and this is not aceptable in a annual sports game... I always complimented Codemasters for not letting F1 games go in the direction of another annual sports games but with this Podium Pass and new "currency" inside the game I can't give a positive review...The game it's fine (I don't play multiplayer so I'm saying this about the singleplayer modes), if you played F1 2019 it's just a natural evolution and managing a team it's nice and rewarding... but the Podium Pass looks like the start of a greedy era, just other games where you have to buy sh*t after you already paid for the game...

[h1] F1 2020 [/h1] is without a doubt, the most polished and well made in the series. That being said, it has a collection of minor flaws that keep the game from reaching true perfection. Some of these flaws are carried over from previous titles, and some are new problems that were created in the process of adding new features.

I will first begin with what is amazing about F1 2020. The most refined feature of this game is not often discussed by many reviewers, and that is the controls. I personally played this game on an Xbox One gamepad with no assists, I had zero problems and the game handles like a dream. While most true sim racing games seemingly require a wheel to play to their full enjoyment, playing F1 2020 on a gamepad has no drawbacks once you get used to it. The key element that makes gamepad controls so smooth is separating force feedback (FF) into different sections based on the source of vibration. While many sim racers (raceroom being a good example) simply make all FF come from the center of the gamepad, F1 2020 assigns brake based FF to the left trigger (using the default controls) and acceleration based FF to the right trigger. This may seem like a simple solution, it smooths the process of playing with no assists considerably, as the player can now feel where the level of grip is more effectively. This also applies to wheel traction as well, so when one of your tires loses traction, you know which one it is based on FF location. This, in combination with many other refinements in gamepad controls, make the non-wheel driving experience easy to understand and improve with. The reason this is not often talked about, is because codemaster's refined control scheme has now become standard in their titles, however I believe it is important for the casual and inexperienced player to know that the barrier to entry is significantly lower because of these features.

While the core gameplay itself is amazing, what about everything surrounding it? Well, to put it simply, if you have played F1 2019, you have already played around 80% of the game before. I say this in the sense that F1 2020 recycles most of the content from the previous year's game. Driver career, championship modes, classic F1 cars and invitational events all make a return. The one big addition to this game is the "my team" mode that puts the player in the position of a team owner, manager, and lead driver. Playing as a modern Jack Brabham is a somewhat refreshing take on the modern sim racer. This feature brings a lot to the table as it gives a racing game something to do other then just racing. It is important to note however, that a large portion of the content in my team is based around the foundation of R&D development from previous games, as the main choices you have to make are around which R&D department to commit to or develop.

One of the more intriguing new features is the addition of driver ratings. In previous F1 games all an AI driver's speed was based on was their car and difficulty setting. With these new driver ratings, each AI driver has their own racing personality of sorts. Because of this, certain drivers might perform better in qualifying then in the race, or be more prone to ballsy overtakes then other drivers. This is especially visible in the "my team" and "driver career" modes, as with driver transfers, certain drivers might out perform their car, an example from my save being how Daniel Ricciardo consistently qualifies higher in a Mclaren than Alex Albon in a Red Bull, even though Daniel has a clearly inferior car. This small addition to the game makes quite a difference overall in the feeling of realism, as each driver feels like their own entity and no longer just an embodiment of their constructor. This also blends well with the my team mode, as it now creates a meta-game out of the driver market, as you can choose which driver to approach based on the stats your team needs.

Most of F1 2020 is pure gold, however there are small pebbles and stones that keep this gem from truly shining. The biggest problem stems from the new addition of the podium pass. The podium pass is just what it sounds like, a battle pass...for F1. If you do not care about cosmetics then you can skip this section because the PP (yes I am abbreviating it like that) only unlocks visual cosmetics for the player. The PP comes with the additional features of challenges and a daily items shop, clearly emulating the microtransactions of games like Fortnite. If you are willing to pay the 10ish dollars to unlock the premium PP, it gives the game a sense of progression aside from the career modes, but if you do not, there are some small consequences. The most obvious consequence is the lack of basic cosmetics, while F1 2019 gave the player more than a dozen options for helmet designs from the beginning, F1 2020 gives only [i] five [/i] (not counting DLC). Car liveries are in a similar position as only four are unlocked from the beginning, with a couple others being unlockable via grinding. Codemaster's rational for this is quite obvious, as they likely plan on re-releasing the designs from F1 2019 in the items shop throughout the year. Sidenote: Codemasters has also not yet added a way to record color coordinates for the combinations to achieve certain colors, so the process of copying a color off of a different design involves eyeballing what the color looks like.With all that being said, the customization in this game is fantastic. because of their new podium pass system, codemasters is now free to branch out more with their designs, allowing more original cosmetics like the "star and stripes" series, that have more unique design ideas. 

A common criticism from previous games is that each game has been using the same set of basic character animations since F1 2016. Sadly, this is still true, while I was hopeful that the addition of custom podium celebrations might signal CM attempting to create new animations, they remain the same, as do some of the pit lane graphics and computer screens. Sidenote: if you look closely at the pit lane engineer's computer screens, they all have a map of Monaco on them no matter which track you are on.

This is a truly fun game to play, with fantastic core gameplay, and a host of new additions that freshen up the "formula" of this franchise (yeah I want to punch myself in the face after that pun too). Overall, F1 2020 is an amazing game, and if you are willing to either shell out an extra $10 or simply put up with a lack of cosmetic options, any seasoned sim racer or casual driver can enjoy themselves playing this game.

Edit: CM added in color values for customization, hopefully they will later add the ability to manually change sponsor locations on helmets (without changing the location on the car livery).

First thing first, I want to specify from the beginning that I have played every single F1 game that Codemasters has made.

Now...in the last couple of days I really wanted to play F1 2020 online, but is simply UNPLAYABLE!!!

It is simply ridiculous how every single time something has to go wrong in a way or in another.

Sometimes there is someone in the lobby who wants to kill you, or you have to wait a lot for everybody to connect properly while you are watching the endless loading screen, or the ghost system simply doesn't work and you can't know when you can go through a car and when you will hit someone who was a ghost but became a proper car, or you can't overtake because the other players have lag and you can't know where they are going and you end up hitting them, or you remain stuck in the pits for 10 or 20 seconds because why not....

The damage model is too fake.A lot of times you hit something with the front-left of the car and something from the other side of the car detaches. I heard about the licensing problems. But they can't be the reason for the unbreakable rear wing, floor, barge-boards and so on. It would be nice to see that your suspension is a bit damaged after you touched a wall in Monaco.  

Not to mention the safety car and the way it gets deployed. It is inconsistently and that is when it finally gets deployed, because most of the times there is a yellow flag for anything and then, suddenly, the SC is deployed for a car that stopped on the track.

I mean, I can understand that nothing is perfect. I do love the game, the graphics are outstanding and the sounds are really good. But, at the end of the day, it is simply unacceptable to buy a game that has so many problems. And what is truly sad is the fact that these issues have been in the game since the move to the Next Gen Consoles, back in 2015. When you really think a bit, it is outrageous to pay 50-60 euros every year for something that barely improves. The price isn't too big, the game is the real problem.

From my point of view a lot of things that are in the game are awesome but they are not fully implemented or they are not used at the maximum potential. For example, the My Team Carrier Mode is done just to be done. It is really nice to be able to make your own team, and choose your favourite colors. But you can't really choose your livery or the colors. You need to fall in love with one of the liveries that are in the game, and you will not be able to modify the color of the number, which is black on the most of the cars and doesn't fit at all with the rest of the car. You can't really go into administration as your balance will never drop below 0. In the normal Carrier Mode, you can lose your drive if you under-perform, which is great, but it is in fact a loop, as you will always receive new offers from other teams. The historic cars are nice, but they are useless. They are in the game just to be there. You can have a couple of events during your carrier, but it is unrealistic to have a little race in Suzuka, when you are a Renault Team driver and you just finished the race in Monaco, with the next round being in Baku. Also the V8s are super slow on a straight line, they were slower back then, but not that slow. You can't go over 300 km/h at Spa. I would also like to have a full season of cars, even pay extra for them, and play something like a Carrier Mode from 1999, for example.

And I am not writing this just to write it. I know that it might even end up unread or a small amount of people will see it. But, What I want to say is that I will stop buying F1 games until these issues get fixed and also the racing and driving aspects of the game become more realistic. I want to be able to put the car on the grid by myself after the formation lap, I want to actually drive through the pit lane, I want to see realistic damage, red flags, more tracks.

The game is great, but when I play it I have a feeling that it is such an old game. And that's because it is so repetitive, and sometimes annoying and unrealistic.

List of game-breaking games:
- AI keeps driving into from the back of your car until you spin off the track. As soon as they make contact, they just keep pushing.
- If you drive next to an AI, they ram into you if that is their 'optimal' race line
- Game disqualifies you randomly for not using 2 tyre compounds, even though you pitted for different tyres
- VSC and safety car are a buggy mess: safety car delta is unreliable, leading to drive through penalties even though you're standing still on track, pit lane + safety car leads to punishments
- Sound breaks volume of many other applications (like teamspeak/discord) until your alt+f4 out of f1 2020
- Game randomly loses controller and when you plug it in again it doesn't  recognize your controller config
- If you need to fulfill a drive-through penalty, the game pits you instead of drive-through, making it impossible to do the drive-through, which leads to disqualification.

The game is borderline unplayable in its current state.

F1 2020 is quite possibly the most in-depth and accessible Codemasters F1 game so far. Codies has managed to deliver a game that appeals to casual race fans and dedicated F1 fans as well. First things first, though, this game is NOT a simulator.

 If you go into this game expecting a realistic representation of how an F1 (and F2 car) drives then you will be disappointed. This game can be classified as a simcade (an already loose definition in the first place) at best. However, this does not mean the game isn't fun. Driving in this game is intensely fun, especially with assists turned off, you can still really 'fight' the car for control. Using a wheel is probably the best way to enjoy this game, although controller users can still have a lot of fun as well especially with the new 'casual' mode offered by the game. 

Now that i've touched on how the game delivers the feel of driving an F1 car, this game definitely succeeds in making you FEEL like an F1 driver. With the game's attention to detail for every team (cars, team kits, and garages) from the F2 feeder series, media interviews, car R&D, and driver transfers, the game tries it's best to give players the feeling that they are a fully-fledged member in the F1 paddock. The one thing that i wish was more in-depth is the MyTeam mode. It's fun for around 3 seasons, but after the 4th season onwards, everything gets a bit stale even with the dynamic driver transfers. The lack of proper customization for your cars and driver gear is also disappointing. Although i can understand why, this is the first time Codies tried pulling off something like this with a license as big as Formula One.

On the technical side of things, however, the game does suffer a bit from a few annoying physics-related, graphical bugs and 1 game-breaking save glitch (which i think is sorted by the time of writing this review). Despite the heavily improved AI from previous games, you can still experience weird inconsistencies from the AI performance in qualifying sessions, and an occasional lack of a challenge from the AI in the higher difficulty settings (AI level Expert/90+).

All in all, this game provides a fresh new challenge for both new and returning players in the MyTeam mode and has more accessibility for casual players by providing more assists and help options to ease players in the world of F1. Besides that, the existing regular career mode is refined and better than ever with the addition of a full F2 season. Minor bugs and inconsistencies aside, F1 2020 is a game that both F1 fans and casual players alike can enjoy. 81/100.

[h1]Se você gosta de F1 e quer um bom jogo para ligar e jogar, esse é o jogo.[/h1] 

Ou seja, não tem que ficar instalado mods, apps ou configurações mágicas. É basicamente ligar e jogar.

Os gráficos estão excelentes. Um pouquinho melhores que o F1 2019. Os modos de jogo são vários, sendo que agora tem o My Team, que não tinha no F1 2019.

As pistas são todas originariamente previstas no calendário no início do ano. Por isso, infelizmente as mudanças que a F1 sofreu devido ao COVID19 não foram aplicadas. Desta forma, pistas como Hockenhein, Mungello, Imola e Algarve não estão e [b]não estarão[/b] no jogo. Por outro lado, as pistas originariamente previstas e que devido ao COVID19 saíram do calendário, estão no jogo. Assim, Zandvoort, Hanoi, Interlagos, Austrália, Canadá etc estão todas no jogo, apesar de não mais fazer parte do calendário final da F1 2020.

Em termos de jogabilidade no volante, não percebi grandes mudanças. O carro continua perigoso nas escorregadas de traseira. Mas isso, é claro, se você forçar um setup com menos aderência na traseira, o que particularmente eu gosto de fazer e normalmente não acaba bem. rs

Comparado ao F1 2019, o jogo é melhor? Na minha opinião, é sim. Mas por pouco. Por isso, o jogo pode não valer a pena para aqueles que não são tão ligados à F1 e estão pensando num jogo só para sentir o gostinho de pilotar um carro de F1. Mas se o jogador quer pilotar o melhor jogo/simulador da temporada 2020 da F1, na minha opinião, este jogo é a melhor opção do mercado atualmente. Por isso, na minha opinião o jogo vale cada centavo e é 100% recomendado.

Like a many racing titles before it F1 2020 falls into common pitfall of extremely lacking AI difficulty quality control. One race they will be 2-3 seconds slower than you and next race they will be 2-3 seconds faster, which either require player to constantly tweak difficulty settings before each race (essentially running a mock session outside of career mode) or forfeit any hopes for a challenging race.

It's a real shame because game packs a lot of content, which is ultimately rendered not interesting due to difficulty issues.

Adding to the insult is the fact that once you're in qualifying you can't change the difficulty settings, therefore if you notice it being wrong there you have nothing left to do except to forfeit the race.

As per usual, its a game made for kids... no realism, no real racing, same garbage like the other iterations!

[h1]Great racing game for those interested in racing games[/h1]

[u]As you would expect[/u]
[b]F1 2020[/b] is as most people would expect - a great racing game with great graphics.
Having only played about 2hrs total, I can't say too much about content and gameplay, however, I've seen that [b]F1 2020[/b] has great gameplay.

[u]Customization[/u]
Being able to customize your vehicle is a nice thing to make the game more personal - and you can do quite a bit.
You are also able to create your own character from developer-made presets [i]face, hair, hat, etc.[/i]

[u]Other things[/u]
One of the things they did well with this F1-game is that they provided us with [b]26 tracks![/b]
Which is great for the people that love to drive on different tracks, or for those that would love to drive on one the tracks in real life; but can't.
The career more is also great.

[u]Playable on keyboard[/u]
I would highly suggest playing with a wheel, like any other racing/car game.
However, playing with a keyboard is not as hard as you maybe thought.

[u]Worth the money?[/u]
[b]F1 2020[/b] is definitely worth the money if you are interested in racing, or racing games.
If you haven't played any games from the F1 genre before, this would be the perfect one to start with.

I think this is the perfect example, that Codemasters is heading into the wrong direction. Don't get me wrong. You see that I still play it, and if there would be a sideways thumb, I would take it, because the game is not bad but also not really good. 

It stagnates and that is making it difficult to recommend. Codemasters is trying to buff the content, but not fix the gameplay. The AI is still bad and is inbalanced. They just have more top speed if you increase the difficulty. So it varies too much. 
Online is still a mess and is impossible to play. But the biggest flaw is Myteam. It shows the community, that there is a new mode, but really, it is not much more than the normal career. There is no depth to the decisions. 
What I want is more realistic gameplay. 
Basically a better collision model (Tires still or rear not affected by contact), weather/track conditions (10 rounds on a track that stops being wet, but the dry tires are still slow, because the computer suggested HEAVY WET?!), a complete warm up lap with parking the car and also driving into parc fermé after the race etc. I could go on for hours. 
So stuff, that is more important than more content, because that content is easily made, but gameplay changes, physics adjustments are way harder and are costing more money. So as a fan, I fear that it will just be a FIFA in a few years.

Good.  However, game does not recognize when AI, or players on online ranked "bump" you off the track. For example, Monza is horrible if you have pole position. You always get "bumped off" the track even though I'm in an S-Rank safety rating lobby. However, the game recognizes this as corner-cutting if you get bumped off and rejoin further up the chicane, even though this is perfectly legal in real world racing. Its 2020, we should not have this issue.

I do however commend them on the "ghosting" improvements in online ranked, when someone goes off the track they are ghosted and less likely to completely derail you. However, these quality of life improvements do not require an entire new game to be released, just a small software update would do.

Overall 8/10.

One of the deepest racing games currently going, F1 2020 somehow finds a way to improve on an already super-solid formula. I've sank most of my game time into the new "My Team" mode; a really fun twist on the usual career that has you start a team from scratch and operate everything along the way, including hiring drivers and choosing whereabouts to invest sponsorship prize money and general funds. It's been a long time since I've put so much time into a game so quickly and it's largely thanks to this new mode. Obviously the race calendar follows a 2020 season set in a world where COVID didn't happen, and so a lot of this year's allocated venues in the real championship are not featured; understandable considering the development window and release timing. Nevertheless, 100% recommended for racing enthusiasts.

Pros:
- Race weekend events where you can race others on the track where the real F1 event is being held
- Realistic audio quality (the sound of the engines is amazing)
- Customisation options (Your multiplayer car, character, team etc.)

Cons
- Literally no point in playing F2 (Don't assume that by completing F2 you'll be put into F1 teams accordingly)
- F2 practice session is redundant (I think its geared towards people who have little to no experience in open-wheeled motorsport racing). There is no incentive to complete the practice sessions.
 - Not sure if it was only me that experienced it, but the Oceania server was quite laggy and limited so most of the time I was racing on Asia/America servers with moderately high ping.

As you can see most of my complaints are related to my F2 career. This is because i fell into the trap thinking that doing well in F2 would put me in a good team in F1. Boy was I disappointed when I completed my F2 career... You could total your car and score 0 points in your whole F2 career and still have the option to join Mercedes, Redbull etc. At the end of your F2 career, you are simply given a list of teams to join rather than being placed in a team based on your skills and effort. So ultimately, there is no point completing the F2 career.
All in all, the game is great and still sorta worth the $84.95 but I wouldn’t bother with the F2 career. Just skip it and get to the good stuff straight out of the box.

Initially I gave this game a positive review as it was an improvement on F1 2019 and is overall fun to play. The fundamental downside about this game is that the servers are always buggy, it seems like Codemasters do not care about maintaining their servers as I along with many of the guys I do league races with find ourselves losing connection or getting kicked from races, which is incredibly frustrating when you want to do well. Another huge issue is the incident/crash detection system. The game is not smart enough to pickup who caused accidents and incidents. If following a safety car and you are hit from behind the game gives the victim a five second penalty or drive through penalty. When racing and you are crashed into or crash into an impossible to avoid collision ahead, the game will penalize you. In almost all situations where you are a victim, the game will penalize you anyway. The game is honestly so useless in this catagory, what is the point of having a penalty system if it is completely flawed. I expect better from Codemasters. If this is the case in the next game, I wont bother buying it.

Most refined F1 game so far. The MyTeam mode is a great addition and it is great being able to take a team from the bottom of the field to fighting for podiums alongside the big three. The regular career mode is still here as well, where you get to put your own character into any of the ten F1 teams. Both of these modes are great for sinking time into, considering that a few years ago we didn't even have a career mode.

In terms of the realism/simulation aspect, i've always felt that the Codemasters entries always had that right balance of being realistic enough to keep you on your toes but not being as unforgiving as other sims such as iRacing.

Edit: Public MP lobbies are rage inducing.. grrrr

With the addition of Team Mode, I have a renewed interest in playing through multiple career mode seasons. Glad to see they are continuing to expand on F2, although I'd like to see an F2 Team Mode too. One of the two new tracks, Zandervoort, feels amazing and they did a great job bringing it to live. I haven't spent much time playing online yet so I can't speak to any improvements there (ranked matchmaking works better I hope). I'll update the review after putting some more time in but overall, the F1 2020 is feels very similar to F1 2019 with a few minor improvements to car handling, a couple new tracks and the introduction of the 11th team (which I'm loving so far). I expect to put a few hundred hours into this game by the time 2021 is released. If you haven't played an F1 game before, you are in for a big treat! This is the only racing game series around that actually gets better each year.

[h1] F1 2020 is a MAJOR improvement over its predecessor F1 2019. [/h1]

[b] Here's why; [/b]

[list]
[*] MyTeam mode allowing you to create your own F1 team, becoming the 11th team on the grid. Throughout your MyTeam, you develop your car from being near the last car on the grind to a championship contender. This is a great step forward compared to the model of F1 2019, where you simply join an F1 team and drive for a preexisting team.

[*] The lobby select menu of Online play had a major improvement, in F1 2019 would have problems with incorrectly showing the status of the lobby. Or if you did join a lobby, many times in F1 2019 a connection error would occur and you'd be kicked back to the lobby. The online in F1 2019 felt very unstable, whereas Codemasters has clearly put time into improving the online play for F1 2020. Now online feels very stable with few issues here and there. (Ex: A guy in the lobby is the last one loading for an excessive amount of time, holding up the lobby until either he quits or everyone else quits.

[*] The new ERS system implemented is a gamechanger for the flow of the game. F1 2019 had 5 ERS options, which became tedious in managing throughout the race, having to constantly cycle and manage your ERS on top of your fuel. This was incredibly tedious as if you played on automatic ERS you had a huge pace disadvantage. The overhaul of the ERS system in F1 2020 completely fixes this issue. Now there is two ERS options during the race, overtake, and medium. The player uses overtake when wanting to increase power and attempt to gain time or make an attempt at an overtake. This simplified system improves the flow of the race greatly.
[/list]

[u] Now To Focus On F1 2020: [/u]

[list]
[*] Similar to last year, the feedback on the gamepad is amazing, it gives you so much information on the status of the car. You can feel when you're losing grip, you get feedback on if you are about to lock up the tires, and much more. Codemasters never disappoints when it comes to feedback on the gamepad and I can assume it is the same with Force Feedback on the wheel. 

[*] The graphics of this game are stunning, similar to last year the game is very visually pleasing with great optimization. Allowing for smooth gameplay with great scenery.
[*] Codemasters added a podium pass this year, which is the same as the battlepass models of other genres. This is a great system for players to earn cosmetics as they continue to play the game. No advantages or disadvantages are earned through the podium pass or any DLCs you can buy. 

[*] The AI for this game continues to be the best AI of any racing game to date. There is still some flaws. An example would be the AI struggling to have wheel to wheel battles with the players. Overlooking the small flaws of the F1 2020 AI, the AI itself is top of its class and gives a very immersive feeling while racing in MyTeam. 
[*] CodeMasters included the original career mode mentioned before for the players that enjoy the more traditional career mode in F1 games. This allows for the player to choose between playing MyTeam or just doing the career they know and love, or both. 
[/list]

Overall a very immersive and fun game, with endless hours of entertainment. In my opinion, this is the most innovative game of the F1 series to date, as well as the most enjoyable. We are currently in the prime of the F1 series. 9.5/10.
absolutely a blast for F1 fans

f1 2020 is a complete package of a racing games. Career, My Team, Online Racing, Split Screen, etc makes this game very recommended. Although this game still has a lot of bug and glitch which annoying me so much.

Just a little reference before we get into the review : this is officially my first racing game with a wheel. I started watching Drive to Survive on Netflix and before you know it, F1 was in my library and a steering wheel was in my house. Lot of questions were asked, specifically around why is there a wheel in the living room and what was the cost. That doesn't matter; what does matter is that F1 2020 has come a long way since I first played the series in 2015. Rock solid racing game, a lot funner with friends, and highly recommended with a wheel. Although the game is quite positive, there are still a few things to consider depending on your level of competitiveness. 

F1's [b]gameplay[/b] is quite rock solid. The amount of assists available to help new players makes the game accessible and allows n00bs to experience success to continue playing. If there is a need for a more real, racing simulation type action, turn off all those assists and start wondering why the car continues to spin out (maybe don't floor it at first eh)? That was the first major difference I noted. Actual F1 fanatics will notice systems like DRS and ERS are avaialble, and pit/boxing the car can all be made manual as well. I got a few speeding penalties in the pits for that. The single player mode features two main paths : Career and My Team. 

Career is what you'd expect, start from F2 and work your way to F1. Become a better driver, make more money, earn more sponsors, and race for the dream team you've always wanted. My Team takes a more manager/owner approach where you manage more than you drive. Time trials is also available - times are recorded and compared to worldwide players so there is always motivation to try harder. Multiplayer features split screen (nice touch really), unranked and ranked lobbies. Ranked generally has players that are more "race smart" and are wary of colliding with others. Sometimes in unranked you'll find lobbies like this, but sometimes you will lose your marbles as some players do not grasp the concept of a proper F1 race. Dive-bombing (going at a fast speed into a turn and hitting another car) can be a real issue and really piss off serious drivers. Some players have an issue discerning between Need for Speed collisions and F1 collisions. 

The [b]graphics and visuals[/b] are pretty good. Animations seems smooth and accurate, graphics take note of tires skidding onto the track, and the dynamic weather system is a pretty cool feature. There will be races where you'll start in rain, but maybe finish racing in the sun. Really changes the strategy and forces the player to apply their common sense in a racing situation. I understand that F1 keeps safety paramount, but knowing that F1 2020 is a game, I think this realm needs a little work. If a car travelling at 300km/h hits another car or a wall, there should be some damage and potentially some flips going on. I think this is the weakest point of the game at the moment. The [b]sounds and music[/b] are bland. Some of the engine sounds are definitely distinct, while others may seem like a modified vacuum. The interviews after races are a little annoying after a while; interviewers will ask more or less the same questions which affect the player's acclaim. 

Overall, F1 2020 is a solid kick to the new decade. I highly recommend the game if you follow F1, if you're an avid and competitive racing fan, or own a steering wheel and pedals. I think the price of the game is a little high and should be towards the $30-$40 range. I disagree with releasing games year after year with no significant improvement (*cough cough* I'm looking at you FIFA). If you do decide to purchase this, 

I would recommend getting a few friends on board and creating or joining a league. Small details like the crowd suddenly cutting out, or the absence of punctured tires may bug you for the price of $60+. Reviewing replays is also another terrible feature that needs significant improvement. I think for $60+, the replay system should be at least decent. Additionally, the ranking system doesn't make much sense. My ranking and license both go down and up randomly at times. It would be nice to know what I'm doing right in the game and what I'm doing wrong. F1 2020 is a decent game, but is a long way away from being superior to iRacing.

2020 and still no VR support despite the community begging for it for years! No actual triple screen support either. Multiplayer still sucks. No mouse support. Physics and force feedback were improved a bit this year but still feel like trash compared to real racing sims like iRacing or ACC.  There is a reason the real F1 drivers think the game is a joke and refuse to play it. They all play mostly  iRacing or Rfactor instead. I really wanted to love this game but with the lack of VR and poor physics other sims just do everything better than F1 2020 can (other than F1 licensing obviously).

If you're the type that plays the game casually on a controller for a couple weeks and don't mind re-buying essentially the same game each year (think madden) because you love F1 so much than you'll probably be ok with the game. But if you use a wheel and are the type that wants to play a racing game for months on end. This isn't that game for you. You'll get bored very fast.  There is pretty much no depth to the F1 driving model. For a lot of replayability you'll need actual racing sims that have more complex physics.

After hearing they made FFB more realistic this year I was excited to try and really wanted to love this game as I'm a huge F1 fan but after playing for a couple hours I wasn't that impressed. I hopped back over to iRacing and drove an F3 car. It took me about two turns to realize there is absolutely no reason for me to ever play F1 2020. With other games, I'm able to be fully immersed in VR while driving a bigger variety of cars that all handle much better. There is no reason to buy this when there are so many other racing games out there that do everything so much better.

If you're just looking for some happy go lucky gamepad/controller driving... oooo look mum I beat Lewis Hamilton oooo look we've been to that track! Then sure, it's a fun time decent looking game to feel like you're involved with Formula 1.  Fill your boots you'll very likely enjoy it.

I'm a casual sim driver.  By that I mean I own a direct drive wheel, a cockpit, pedals and have a decent rig, but I don't compete in anything, I'm a very good sim driver, I can jump into a good sim and match the real pole times of the real drivers and that's what I enjoy doing, but I don't take it seriously at a competition level.  What I enjoy is the feeling of the cars and knowing that you're close to the real thing.

Obviously in todays world, your opinion doesn't mean anything unless you're popular so don't take my word for it... take George Russells, lead driver for the Williams F1 team who described F12020 as a "step in the right direction".  This summed it up perfectly for me.  Codemasters have been working on this franchise for 12 years and they're still unable to get it right.  And that step in the right direction? They need thousands more steps before they're at the right place.

The Formula 1 2020 game... you don't have to have driven a Formula 1 car to know that these cars are absolutely nothing remotely like the real thing, they don't drive or behave anything like a Formula 1 car to levels where it's just not fun at all.  I respect the guys who top the leaderboards in the game and are able to get these cars around the tracks faster than everyone else, but they're not driving a F1 car, they're delicately choreographing.  The real 2020 Formula 1 cars are designed to be the grippiest vehicles ever made, you just need to look at one real race to see the insanity in how nimble they are, precise, they throw them into corners and the outrageous levels of downforce plant the cars into the road like there's a planet resting on them... 
This game though? The cars feel like you're pushing a hovercraft around an ice lake.  They're cumbersome, slippery even with maximum downforce settings, they understeer off the road at will, break traction far too easily, you think you're the problem until you look at how these cars behave in real life and in other games/sims and you realise no, they're just that bad here. 

Part of the problem is the woefully inadequate force feedback that the game provides, it has gotten better over the years, but it's missing key feedback to let you know what's going on with the car.  For example, you can hit 215mph on the Monza pit straight, turn your wheel to full lock to which the car then begins to understeer in an almost perfect straight line... this wouldn't happen but that's not the point, but whilst the car has completely lost all grip with the road and is essentially free sliding in a straight line there is absolutely zero feedback being sent to your wheel to let you know that the car has lost traction.  There's a very minor amount of loss in tension as part of the understeer effect, but blink and you'll miss it, and that's it.  You can be free sliding with zero traction at 200mph and the game sends no feedback through to your wheel, making knowing whats going on almost impossible.  Other titles do a great job with this by juddering the wheel during loss of grip, it's unrealistic but so is sitting still whilst travelling at 200mph, you need false feedback to simulate car physics.  This is just one of many examples where you're left feeling like you're fighting a losing battle if you want to drive the car to the best of your ability, without all that you're just driving it like you're trying to master a game mechanic.  Now you can play around with damper settings and all the rest of it as much as you want, the feedback is decent in most areas in terms of bumps in the road and rumble strips but when you need to know that you've broke traction going through maggots & beckets... there's nothing.

Then there's other things like track limits which ruin the experience for those of us who enjoy shooting for leaderboard times.  The FIA have pretty clear guidelines on where track limits are per track, but Codemasters have completely ignored those and it's almost like they've asked an intern to red-line the boundary of the tarmac as track limits at times... areas where you absolutely have to take the car as part of the corner are deemed a disqualification when in real life it's totally acceptable to be there.  I appreciate these limits are the same for all users, but that's not the point I'm making, the point is this makes the driving experience as an individual far less enjoyable.  Speaking of leaderboards though, the game has a chronic problem with hackers cheating their times to the top of the boards.  I've witnessed the guy at no.1 on a leaderboard, watched his ghost, his car floated backwards around the track upside down and finished the lap 20 seconds quicker than everyone else... and his time stayed there for months.  Codemasters just don't give a toot.  

Look, the counter argument you always hear when people complain about F1 games is that "they're not a sim" and "stop being an elitist" or words to that effect.  But I totally disagree.  Codemasters do want this to be a sim, there are numerous elements to this game such as telemetry outputting and compatibility profiles with high end simulator gear which suggests they do want this to be considered a simulator.  But the fact that they also try and cater for a console audience on gamepad/controller makes this a mushy confused mess of a game which just doesn't work for those of us who just want a reasonably realistic driving experience, it's not enjoyable to drive and in my opinion they should allow something as prestigious as the Formula 1 license to be given to a dedicated simulation studio in addition to catering for the masses.  It really is saying something when you can download a $3 mod for something like Assetto Corsa, the RSS Hybrid car, and have a far more accurate feeling Formula 1 driving experience than the actual franchised game.

Let's not forget, Codemasters can't even be bothered to enable mouse support in the PC version of the game, when you're at that level you do have to cast doubt on why other things are so questionable in the game.

And finally, VR support.  I'm personally tired of hearing the excuse that it isn't worth putting in because so few people have a VR headset.  No.  So few people have a VR headset because so few mainstream developers are able/capable or willing to make their title compatible with VR.  It's the other way around.  It's a futile argument, but mark my words, at some point the person who decides on who gets the F1 game license will eventually be enlightened into the world of VR, and they'll come down on Codemasters like a ton of s**t over why it hasn't been part of their game for all this time.

So sure, there are parts of the game which are good and detailed, as a casual gamers you'll probably love it, but for anyone who wants to feel like you're actually driving something close to a F1 car with a wheel and pedal set, it's a far cry from that.  And as a Formula 1 fan it's very disappointing to not have that connectivity with the sport.

It's terrible. It's not clear at all how to simply race. I've had the thing for hours now, nothing but bollocks to deal with.

As a midfield team, was forced to choose my rival between Hamilton and Bottas. Obviously it was impossible to compete with either of them.

Archaic Saving system, completely unable to have multiple saves for one career, forcing you to continue in midst of slight errors. Haven't had to deal with this issue since the early 2000s in video games. Essentially the game is stuck on permanent Ironman mode.

Constant crashing near the end of races, and strange visual glitches whilst tailing cars during rainy races. This visual bug causes the screen to violently flash bright lights, anyone prone to seizures be warned...

Claire, the interviewer, will bring up non existent instances of crashes, collisions, or wall-scrapes, despite nothing happening.

There is little to NO continuity between AI difficulty on every track. Some tracks, the AI are painfully slow, and on others, are brutally OP. 

The Qualifying Practice Programme gives you a target time that accounts for your engine mode being in MAX, despite FORCING you to drive in RICH engine mode at best. Essentially, if your Qualifying Practice Programme states your qualifying time was good enough for 15th, in the real race, that pace is usually AT LEAST 5 positions better. In short, the Qualifying Practice Programme is way more difficult than it should be.

Probably the best F1 game currently, slight improvements over F1 2019 but they are noticeable, like tyres going off the pace and you can feel the grip more, or lack of  lol  My Team is good but end of the day it's career mode but you have options to upgrade your facilities, sign sponsors, sign drivers and dictate the direction your R&D takes. Only downside is that each race weekend takes a while unless you just skip straight to the race which is minimum 5 laps long, however doing this means you lose out on precious R&D points, doing this manually normally means you will get the full amount but by simulating you run the risk of getting substantially less. Multiplayer works fine, I've only done ranked races and can always find a lobby. The one downside to doing ranked is the 'strict' corner cutting that is employed and at times is laughable as you only have to touch the white line and you're warned, likewise if someone crashes into you you will always get a warning for a collision which is very harsh.

Overall, buy it if you don't own F1 2019, if you own F1 2019 (like I do) then it comes down to you really but in hindsight I would wait for it to go on sale.

[h1]F1 2019 vs F1 2020[/h1]

[i]- Looks about the same.[/i]
[b]Is 2020 Gameplay better?[/b]
[i]- Yes[/i]
[b]Is 2020 better overall?[/b]
[i]- yes[/i]
[b]Is 2020 worth the upgrade?[/b]
[i]- Yes[/i]
[b]So does that mean 2020 is now the best F1 game?[/b]
[i]- Yupp[/i]


[h1]F1 2019 Review[/h1]
[quote][h1]F1 game for the masses[/h1]
[b]DLC’s[/b] let’s just get that out of the way, just don’t bother getting any of them, you not missing anything nor does if effect your gameplay. Just leave it…

[b]Difficulty,[/b] well it’s a game for the masses, you can make it really hard or you can make it really easy and arcade like. Does not feel like it compromises in whatever you prefer. If you like to game on a controller or steering wheel, both work perfectly fine and can be adjusted to your gameplay style.

[b]Graphics,[/b] I’m running everything on ultra but never had an “oh wow” moment. Have some other Codemasters games also from 2019 where I actually had those moments.

[b]Gameplay,[/b] rock solid! You do need to think about your components in your car, as in you don’t want to wear them to fast or they do break and you will get a DNF. Planning ahead does feel rewarding, to upgrading to driving more carefully to saving fuel or spare the few tires you got, or just simple heat management. It’s all there with develop new parts to installing them or just speeding up your pit times. That said I never felt overwhelmed by it, all been easy to understand also there are ton of tutorials in the game with solid voice overs and text.

[b]Previous F1 games,[/b] well I have not played one for more than a decade sooo… That said I’ve played tons racing games since Stunts that you played on DOS back in the early 90’s, just not the F1 series.

[b]Link:[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/id/Scorpidoo/recommended/928600/
[/quote]

F1 2020 is a great game, i recommend it for anyone who likes or watches f1 this game features a driving career were you become a driver and do f1 races and race all the other guys etc. Now the reason you want to get this game is the new feature to this years game the MY Team mode this is were you become a owner AND a driver of a team that you create you can choose your engine supplier get F1 and F2 drives for your team new department upgrades like upgrading the time or how many upgrades you can buy at a time. This game also features driver transfers drivers retiring drives from f2 becoming f1 drivers Sponsors and for your team (and sponsor goals for extra cash.). There is also a online racing mechanic were you can race other drivers in ranked or unranked matches in ranked you basically vs people similar to your rank (you start from unranked and get to build rank like bronze silver gold diamond etc). Overall this is a great game and i recommend it for anybody that likes racing or is interested in buying it i give it a 10/10.

F1 Series by Codemasters is nothing short of amazing. Either for virtual racing enthusiasts and newcomers to racing in general.

The game has features to enhance newcomers experiences with high levels of driving assists. The great part about this is being welcome to a greater portion of potential consumers outside the racing niche.

The game also has zero assists options for veterans. The player can remove assists such as traction control and ABS for a more genuine F1 and F2 experience.

This time, F1 2020 has vastly improved the formula of CM F1 titles, with features additions and graphics enhancements also for handling. F1 2020 has a much better tire model than the previous F1 2019 had. We now have the awesome My Team mode, where you create the 11th team on the grid, race and grind for car improvements during a dynamic career mode we already had previously.

Circuits selection is based on the first 2020 official calendar, so you can count on two brand new and laser scanned tracks as Zandvoort and Hanoi GP. 

Suzuka has taken some love from the devs and now counts with a smoother asphalt after the last chicane that previously had an infamous bump.

Cons lies on older circuits that were made years ago and saddly doesn't stand the test of time, specially with now laser scanned circuits. These circuits are in the form of SPA, Hungaroring and Monaco. I believe they are the only ones left for a major revamp as they feature not realistic cambering, hard tarmac elevation changes that are not there in real life and wonky curbs.

SPA GP circuit is in dire need of a total revamp and possibly from a proper laser scan, as the original we have wasn't made with such technology. Curbs are in totally wrong shape, making it sometimes dangerously high for the car as in the amazing turn 12. Saddly, we have to wait to see a proper Spa-Francorchamps circuit.

The game physics is not on the level of iRacing, Assetto Corsa, rFactor 2 and other sims, but surely does the complete experience of a Formula 1 weekend with full rules and dynamic weather. Graphics are sensational and optimization is high end.

As an old Grand Prix 3 fan...This is the best Formula 1 game made to date. Codemasters still improves on every single title since F1 2016, sometimes strongly, sometimes not that much.

Highly recommend. Infinite amount of entertainment.

Amazing game, I'll go over online first.

Online -

Not much changes in terms of development and additions, except for a few new liveries for the custom car. But also the addition of lapped cars being ghosted, which is great, especially in ranked when people get salty and try to take out the leader. Good stuff on that. Other than that nothing much has changed. Not sure what else they can change but Online is pretty good for right now. Setups are also massively important this year more than any other, and this will be very evident in online, you'll find yourself possibly over a second off, if your using a balanced setup. It's really recommended that you either download or create your custom setup, or else you might find yourself at the back and in danger of being taken out at turn 1.

Single Player - 

My Team, my goodness me. I don't believe anyone ever expected this, but it's incredible, create your own team, appoint your own teamate from F2 Drivers to current F1 Drivers, multiple departments where you can decrease or increase morale. There are plenty of sponsors that are your main source of income, they are also placed onto your car, race suit and helmet. A bit more of customization is a good sight in this game. F1 drivers can now retire as well. The only negative from this game is the slight decrease of AI Aggressiveness, there is no denying there speed, but there wheel to wheel racing has gone down a bit, sometimes they completely turn into you, or just brake and completely back out of a fight, which is pretty inconsistent. The second bad thing are the starts, probably the worst it's been since 2015 in terms of starts, it's nearly impossible to get a good start every time against the AI. It's possible, but unlikely.

Overall, amazing game, small negatives and small bugs, but that's normal. Good job Codemasters.

I am a returning player of the franchise, having last played the 2010, '11 and '12 F1 games. Man am I impressed by the improvements! The cars respond so precisely to the Dualshock4 controller throttle input, it made me enjoy lap after lap after lap right from the very first time I got into the car seat. The audio design of the F1 cars are extremely good too! I watched the real F1 race highlights this season and the car audio was literally the same as in the game. Amazing job overall. Career mode is very very immersive and allows one to engage with it as much as they want, with the option to simulate sessions if you find them cumbersome to do. I loved doing all the sessions all the time because of how well the car reacts to my inputs.

MyCareer is such a fun addition to the game. The same career mode year after year was getting rather repetitive despite the improvements to it, and being able to drive your own car for your own team is always a cool and enjoyable concept.

The customization is pretty nice, cars feel really good to drive and the A.I can provide a decent challenge to average players, though the top drivers still seem to find it a bit too easy even on 110 difficulty.

As usual there are some balancing issues with how quickly you can improve in career, A.I being too quick or too slow on certain parts of certain tracks and I can't speak for online, but otherwise it's one of the best, if not THE best F1 game Codemasters has released to date, in terms of single player content.

[h1] More of the same, Deluxe edition lacking [/h1]
I've marked this as Not Recommended but to be honest it's a very slim margin and if there was a middle of the road 5/10 option, this would be it.

TLDR version: If you liked 2019 you'll like this as it's more of the same, but to it's detriment. Too much recycled content, My Team frustrations with liveries/colours. Second driver growth is painfully slow. Schumacher Edition isn't worth it. 2019 had Senna-Prost content with race events based around points in their career. in 2020 the Schumi edition is just a bunch of cosmetics.

Full Review:
From 2019, the addition of My Team is nice, it's where most of my hours have been put in. Also the handling feels different in a good way.
Sadly though that's all I can kinda highlight as new or different in this over the 2019 version.

As is kinda (sadly) expected from annual titles, there is a lot.. a LOT.. of recycled content from last year or two of F1 games.
-Practice tasks are exactly the same (Track acclim, tyre management, race strat etc.) Which can all be completed in less than one practice session, with no real incentive to do Practice 2 & 3 as once they're done, they're done.
-Paddock interview questions and answers are completely identical to last year, not having any new questions at all, or changing the format feels really lazy.
-Classic content is EXACTLY the same as last year, the same classic championship winning cars like Alonso's Renault, the Brawn GP car etc that were in F1 2019.
-The ERS management on the HUD is the same even though the use of it has been changed, so you have a mostly pointless HUD option to change ers mode but only between Medium/Overtake/None when you already have a toggle button.

There are also a few quality of life things that I feel were missed opportunities and frustrating when playing the game.
-My Team mode resource point generation feels really slow the further along the R&D tree you go.
-Acclaim point growth hits a wall and really starts to become a slow grind.
-In My Team, if you want to try and pick a second driver from the lower ranks  and stick with them, rather than changing drivers with higher skill and contracts, their growth is almost painfully slow, with facility boosts only having a limited effect and activities only giving +2 to a single stat, it really frustrating.
-The custom liveries are such a missed opportunity, only giving you the option to recolour a few templates rather than a full fledged editor like in the Forza or NFS series. Also the colour picker is frustrating as you can't save previously used colours.
-Overtake being an on/off button press rather than a press and hold like in the current F1 cars.

Schumacher Edition
It's really not worth it.
While 2019's Senna/Prost edition gave us a few races and track events based around points in their career at least, this year the Schumacher Edition is just a bunch of cosmetics and nothing else.

Overall
Have I and will I continue to sink hours into this game? Yes
Because if you enjoyed 2019, you'll enjoy 2020, because it's more of the same.
But a bit TOO MUCH of the same.
They could've really gone with something fresher for a new decade of f1 games but there's so much copy-paste from 2019s game it's a real let down.

F1 2020 is easily the best of Codemaster's attempts at making a solid F1 game. 

Pros:
- Great physics. Even though it's not a pure simulation, driving in F1 2020 feels engaging and complex. 
- Awesome AI. The AI produces some great battles and makes for a very solid opponent whatever mode you're playing. 
- My Team mode and driver movements. Adds a cool layer of management to all the racing even though it's not all that feature-rich. 

Cons:
- There still are bugs despite Codemasters using a very old engine. In one case, the game crashed at the final lap of a 50% race. 
- There are micro-transactions. Cosmetics only but still. 
- Locking the Schumacher content behind a DLC is, well, not great.
